text: good morning it's my privilege today to
tell you about Illumina one of the
world's most interesting companies that
you've probably never heard of first
thing you should know about Illumina is
that 90% of all the DNA that's ever been
sequenced in history has been sequenced
on Illumina machines sequencing started
out very much as a very powerful
research tools for people looking at DNA
and RNA but as that research has evolved
our knowledge about how to use
sequencing and human health is also
increased and so now more and more
sequencing is being used for clinical
treatment particularly in diseases like
cancer Illumina has a two-part business
model we sell a wider range of in story
of instruments from $50,000 desktop
machines looks like a printer up to 10
million dollar machines for large labs
the interesting thing about that is to
give you a sense of scale those 10
million dollar machines consume about 10
million dollars worth of consumable
reagents from us every year so think
about that next time you're thinking
about replying or getting those printer
cartridges and replacing them 10 million
dollars is a lot more than we usually
have to pay I'm an electrical engineer
so I think about sequencing probably
differently than a biologist I think of
it as a form of analog to digital
conversion the analog input is a sample
it's usually a blood sample or a saliva
sample from a patient the sequencer
process is that and converts it into a
digital file a standard computer file
it's about a hundred gigabytes and
hundred gigabytes in size the amazing
thing about it when you think about it
though is that that file contains all
the data that you need to conceptually
reconstruct the human being that donated
that sample of course once it's in the
form of data you've only done part of
the task I'll use the example of a
clinician who wants to know really only
one bit of information does the person
have the disease or do they not so a lot
of computation happens in taking that
hundred gigabytes of data and boiling it
down to a single bit and in around 2010
we were looking at our road maps we knew
that sequencing was getting a lower in
cost at an extraordinary rate and even
though it had cost about a billion
dollars at the turn of the century we
could see around 2014 we could do see
sequencing of a whole human genome for
around $1,000 the problem we saw at the
same time as the computation required to
process that data was also going to cost
around $1,000 and we knew that wasn't
going to be good for our customers or
good for us so we set ourselves the
challenge of reducing that cost of
computation by about a hundred times as
you might imagine we obviously be looked
at algorithms we looked at hardware
acceleration and of course we looked at
the cloud and anyone that's looking at
the cloud ends up looking at AWS of
course reliability is incredibly
important to us because if the
computational system breaks down then
there's no sequencing going on that's
bad for the customer and it's bad for us
we're also very driven by cost and we
knew that great cost advantage came from
great scale advantage
so obviously AWS was going to be great
with that we needed unlimited
scalability because we're in exponential
growth mode but we also needed it in an
unusual way we needed it to have a
global footprint genomic data is
incredibly sensitive data and countries
usually don't want it moving outside of
their national boundaries so we needed a
partner like AWS that had an amazing
international footprint and last but not
least we needed a comprehensive strategy
for dealing with security because of the
sensitivity of the data and regulatory
compliance because of the health nature
of that data as well we did choose AWS
otherwise I wouldn't be here talking
with you today and we built a system
that we call base base it is based on a
number of Amazon services most of which
or all of which I'm sure you very
familiar I think the most interesting
thing about base base the unique thing
is we're not just talking to our users
we're also talking to the machines that
sit out in these worldwide user sites
fortunately it takes about 24 hours to
sequence that hundred gigabyte whole
human genome and so that gives us 24
hours to upload the data in parallel
with the actual chemical reactions and
so at the same moment that the sequence
is finished doing a whole human genome
that data is up in the cloud and
accessible so the user doesn't perceive
any delay between sequencing and the
actual triggering of the informatics
this is a time-lapse that shows
sequencing all over the world uploading
to base base from when we started it in
every time you see a flash of light
that's an Illumina sequencer somewhere
in the world doing a sequence and
uploading the data we started off in
North America but it gradually went
worldwide over the last couple of years
and as this runs to a finish you see the
blue pools of data are actually
interesting from what was their
geopolitical point of view because you
can see we're sequencing is happening
around the world and where those pools
of data are being generated and when I
overlay where Amazon has with great
prescient built data sites you can see
that in fact they end up sitting very
much in the middle of all those large
pools of data and I particularly draw
your attention to India where Amazon
just announced a regional data center
and we are just starting to see really
interesting take up an interest in
large-scale sequencing in India at the
same time so there's some interesting
parallel around technological advantage
advance and adoption and also
computation and sequencing happening in
parallel last year there was an
editorial in the journal Nature based on
some modeling done by some researchers
about how much data was being generated
in genomics and they projected that in
the 2025 time frame the amount of
genomic data in the world was going to
be comparable with the amount of social
media data being generated which is
pretty amazing we see some of that here
we're showing the trend for data storage
inside base space clearly this is
quarter by quarter so clearly great
percentage growth quarter by quarter and
clearly in a very exponential mode of
growth so I think there's some validity
to expecting that there'd be pretty
extraordinary data usage running out
into a couple of years in fact with
apologies to Marc Andreessen I would say
that it's actually sequencing not
software that it's going to eat the
world in the end looking towards the
future we're very excited about our
Internet of Things strategy right from
the start with base space we decided to
have the machines uploading their log
files so really their internal
diagnostic information up into the cloud
and that's now reached a really
extraordinary amount so we're seeing
about 270 billion data points
coming up every year from these machines
it's very important to us because we
started loading that data into a
redshift based data warehouse and it
enables us to both drill down and look
at an individual customers usage but
also do analysis of worldwide supply
chains because we're shipping these very
delicate consumables all across the
world and it lets us get ahead of any
problems that might arise before
customers can detect them so in
conclusion I really feel like this
partnership between two leaders in their
respective fields both sequencing and
cloud has demonstrated that cloud
computing can definitely sustain the
extraordinary demands required of it by
sequencing DNA at a global scale but
even more profoundly I think for me
personally it's very clear that we're
laying the foundations here for a
platform there's going to have huge
impact on the way diseases like cancer
are both detected and treated for
decades to come thank you very much
